Chapter 5 deals with the laws of mutation.

It is commonly thought that mutations occur by chance,

but actuality the mechanism behind mutations is

simply still unknown; it does not happens

completely by chance.

Shellfish that live in southern seas or shallow waters are

lighter in color than those of northern seas or deep waters.

Moreover, the leaves of plants growing on the coast

have thicker leaves than plants living in other areas.

Why do these changes occur?

Let's look at some other examples.

The often-used body parts of domestic animals become larger and stronger, while those parts become smaller and weaker.

These changes are passed on to future generations. For example, the wings of birds

with no natural meat-eating enemies will gradually become smaller and devolve.
